A Linear Equation is an equation in the form
a1x1 + a2x2 … + anxn = b

Where a1,a1, … an and b are constants and x1,x1, … xn are the variables. A linear equation may have one variable, two variables, three variables or more. The following are examples of linear equation:

A solution to a linear equation is a sequence of n numbers s1,s1, … sn which when substituted in place of the variables will satisfy the equation. In the equation 5x + 8 = 2x – 4 , we say that -4 is the solution to the equation. In the equation 2x1 + 8x2 + x3 - 4x4 = 1, x1 = 2, x2 = 0, x3 = 1, x4 = 1 is a solution to the equation since
a1x + b1y = c1\na2x + b2y = c2

An independent system of linear equation is a system that has exactly one solution, that is, the ordered pair that corresponds to the point of intersection of the two lines. 
A dependent system of linear equations is a system that has infinitely many solutions, that is, all the ordered pairs corresponding to all the points on the line. 
An inconsistent system is a system of linear equations that has no solution.

Each number in matrix A is called an entry of the matrix. A matrix that has m rows and n columns is called an m by n matrix. We can write it as m x n matrix. If the number of rows and in matrix is equal to the number of columns, that is m = n, then we say that the matrix is a square matrix of order n.

The elements a11,a12,…annn are the entries in the main diagonal of a square matrix. The element aij is the entry in the ith row and jth column or we can also write A = [a(aij )]. A matrix that has m rows and n columns can be denoted by Amn or simply An if it is n x n.

In the examples above, matrix A has 3 row and 3 columns, thus it is 3 x 3; matrix B is 2 x 2; matrix C is 1 x 3; matrix D is 4 x 1; matrix E is 2 x 3. In A, a12 = 5; in B, b22 = 5; in C, c13 = 0; in D, d41 = 1; and in E, e23 = 4.\n\nDefinition: Matrix A = [a(aij )] and B = [b(bij )] are equal if they have the same entries.

If A = [a(a_ij )] and B = [b(b_ij )] are both m x n matrices, then the sum A + B is an m x n matrix C = [c(c_ij )]. To get the sum of A and B, simply add corresponding entries. Remember that only matrices that are of the same size can be added.

If A = [a(a_ij )] is an m x n matrix and r is a real number (called a scalar), then the scalar multiple r A is the matrix C = [c(c_ij )] whose entries are obtained by multiplying each entry of A by r.
If A and B are both m x n matrices, then A + (-1)B = A – B (called the difference between A and B).

If A = [a(a_ij )] is an m x n matrix and B = [b(b_ij )] is an n x p matrix, then the product AB is defined. AB = C = [c(c_ij )] which is an m x p matrix. The (i,j) entry in C is obtained by using the ith row of A and the jth column of B. Note that two matrices can only be multiplied if the number of columns of first matrix is equal to the number of rows of the second matrix.

Examples:
1. If A is 3 x 2 and B is 2 x 4, then AB is 3 x 4 and BA is not defined.
2. If A is 3 x 2 and B is 2 x 3, then AB is 3 x 3 and BA is 2 x 2.
3. If A is 2 x 2 and B is 2 x 2, then AB is 2 x 2 and BA is 2 x 2.

If A = [■(a_ij )] is an m x n matrix, then the transpose of A, A^T =[■(〖a^T〗_ij )], is the n x m matrix defined by 〖a^T〗_ij =■(a_ij ). The transpose of A is obtained from A by interchanging the rows and columns of A.
A. Zero Matrix
A zero matrix (O_mn) is a matrix all of whose entries are zero.
B. Diagonal Matrix
A diagonal matrix is an n x n matrix A = [■(a_ij )] such that a_ij = 0 for i ≠ j. In a diagonal matrix, the entries off the main diagonal are all zero.
C. Scalar Matrix
A scalar matrix is a diagonal matrix where the elements in the main diagonal are equal.
D. Identity Matrix
An identity matrix is a scalar matrix where the entries in the main diagonal are all 1.
E. Upper Triangular
A n x m matrix A = [■(a_ij )] is called upper triangular if a_ij = 0 for i > j.
F. Lower Triangular
A n x n matrix A = [■(a_ij )] is called upper triangular if a_ij = 0 for i < j.
G. Symmetric
Matrix A is said to be symmetric if A^T = A. In a symmetric matrix, entries are symmetric with respect to the main diagonal.
H. Skew Symmetric
Matrix A is said to be symmetric if A^T = -A. In a skew symmetric matrix, all the entries in the main diagonal are zero.

A nonsingular matrices is a special type of a square matrix. Matrix A is said to be nonsingular matrix or invertible if there exists an n x n matrix B such that AB = BA = In . We call B an inverse of A. If B does not exist, then A is singular or noninvertible.
Getting the product AB gives us the product BA which is also the identity matrix. Therefore we say that B is inverse of A and A is nonsingular.
